author: Cheri Carlson
title: Beaches, parks and piers close due to high surf. Here's what to know
text: [Cheri Carlson](/staff/4406860002/cheri-carlson/) The National Weather Service has issued high surf and coastal flood warnings for Ventura County, urging the public to stay off beaches, coastal walkways, piers and jetties. Dangerous waves pummeled the Ventura coast Thursday, damaging structures, flooding roads and injuring several people. With high surf expected through Saturday , officials have closed many local beaches, harbors, coastal campgrounds and parks. Here's what is closed locally as of Friday morning: - City beaches in Ventura and at the Ventura Harbor - All California State Parks beaches and day-use areas in Ventura and Oxnard â€“ Emma Wood, San Buenaventura, McGrath and Mandalay - Oxnard public beaches - County of Ventura beaches and parks â€“ Faria, Hobson, Rincon Parkway RV Area, Kiddy, Silver Strand and Hollywood - Silver Strand Beach parking lot - Port Hueneme Pier - Ventura Pier - Thornhill Broome campground off Pacific Coast Highway - North Beach and Group Camp campgrounds at Emma Wood State Beach Faria Beach campground near Ventura. The county parks department expects the closure to remain in place until Jan. 5. - Ventura Harbor launch ramp and entrance - Channel Islands Harbor entrance To get sandbags: Local agencies offered a list of spots to get free sandbags. Find a list of Ventura County Fire Department locations at vcfd.org/sandbag-stations . A video showing how to use sandbags is available at vcfd.org/news/video-sandbag-basics . The city of Oxnard also will provide sandbags at the city yard, 1060 Pacific Ave., from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. Friday. Find more information about closures or report damage at vcemergency.com . Cheri Carlson covers the environment and county government for the Ventura County Star. Reach her at [cheri.carlson@vcstar.com](mailto:cheri.carlson@vcstar.com) or 805-437-0260.

organizations.name: port hueneme pier - ventura pier - thornhill broome

author: Alessandro Rosini
title: Australian Electoral Commission under cyber attacks 'almost every day'
text:
Australian Electoral Commission under cyber attacks â€˜almost every dayâ€™
The gateway to Australiaâ€™s democracy is coming under attack â€œalmost every dayâ€ but thereâ€™s a desperate plan in place to stop it from happening.
The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) said it was boosting its cyber defences ahead of the federal election, with the agency expecting an increase in attacks leading up to this yearâ€™s federal election.
The move comes amid a wave of cyberattacks on the countryâ€™s biggest government agencies, banking institutions and other organisations.
Sign up to The Nightly's newsletters.
Get the first look at the digital newspaper, curated daily stories and breaking headlines delivered to your inbox.
By continuing you agree to ourTermsand
Privacy Policy.
Acting AEC Commissioner, Jeff Pope, told 7NEWS.com.au this week â€œthereâ€™s actors trying to penetrate our door almost every day, during non-election time and absolutely more so in election timeâ€.
Itâ€™s a concern echoed by executive director of cyber intelligence at Australian cyber security company CyberCX Katherine Mansted.
â€œThere are more foreign governments than ever that have the means and desire to target our democratic institutions, like elections,â€ she told 7NEWS.com.au.
â€œItâ€™s all about just making sure weâ€™ve got that resourcing, and that attention matched to what our foreign adversaries will be investing in because no doubt they will be considering their position and whether itâ€™s worth probing the vulnerabilities of our democracy.â€
Cyber Security Shadow Minister, James Paterson, expressed concern about overseas influence adding â€œitâ€™s virtually certain that some actors, including foreign actors, will try and exert their influence over this electionâ€.
The AEC is working alongside Australiaâ€™s security agencies and is â€œalert to bothâ€ attacks from foreign and domestic operators.
â€œWeâ€™ve withstood all of that incredibly successfully, weâ€™ve been able to move with increased threats and deter and resist those,â€ the organisation said.
â€œWe are working with our national security and intelligence partners to make sure that we have got absolutely the best protections in place around those cyber security measures.â€
The local response comes after Romaniaâ€™s constitutional court annulled its election results last month when declassified documents revealed evidence that cyberattacks, and foreign interference influenced its election results.
Lecturer in cybercrime at the University of Portsmouth Anda Solea commented on the annulled election, saying â€œRomania was the target of over 85,000 cyberattacks before and during election dayâ€.
â€œThese attacks disrupted the IT and communication infrastructure supporting the electoral process,â€ Solea said.
â€œThe declassification of documents by Romanian intelligence services ... exposed evidence of voting manipulation through social media platforms, illegal campaign financing on TikTok, cyber-attacks orchestrated by external forces and suspected Russian interference.â€
Paterson slammed Laborâ€™s response to foreign interference and said the government needed to do more.
â€œIâ€™m very concerned that the Federal Government has done very little to actually prepare against the serious risk of foreign interference through social media during the election... public opinion can be influenced by social media, particularly through foreign-headquartered social media platforms (such as TikTok),â€ Paterson said.
The attack on Romaniaâ€™s election is not the first time Moscow has been accused of election interference with a US intelligence committee finding â€œample evidence to suggest that the Russian government was developing and implementing capabilities to interfere in the 2016 elections, including undermining confidence in US democratic institutions and voting processesâ€.
However, since 2016, artificial intelligence technology has grown in sophistication, increasing the number of tools available to bad actors.
Katherine Manstead noted that although Australia has one of the most resilient electoral systems in the world, it is important to remain alert.
â€œThe threat actors are multiplying and theyâ€™re more determined than ever before ... We will see, no doubt some threat actors attempt to interfere with or attempt to target our elections.â€
The AEC said it was concerned about AI-instigated cyberattacks on the commission, but is confident in its existing defence strategy.
â€œWe are absolutely enhancing all of our cyber defences in order to protect our systems and particularly our election management system and the election results.â€
Pope said that he was â€œcomfortableâ€ with the current arrangements the AEC has in place related to artificial intelligence and that they would â€œconsider what that legislative framework needs to look like going forward.â€
â€œNothing is ever 100 per cent certain and the sophistication level of cyberattacks as weâ€™ve seen around the globe is increasing and, again, we are very alert, not yet alarmed,â€ he said.
The Annual Cyber Threat Report revealed that Australians can expect more cyberattacks from foreign nations as tensions continue to rise.
â€œThe threat of state-sponsored cyber operations is persistent and will likely grow as strategic competition in the Indo-Pacific increases.â€
â€œState-sponsored cyber actors will continue targeting Australian governments, critical infrastructure, and businesses, as well as connected systems and their supply chains, for espionage and information-gathering purposes,â€ the report found.
Originally published on 7NEWS
topics: Science and Technology->information technology and computer science

author: Reece Kilbey
title: 2023-64 GRAND JURY INDICTS FOUR OCCC INMATES FOR MANSLAUGHTER IN DEATH OF CHRISTOPHER VAEFAGA
text:
2023-64 GRAND JURY INDICTS FOUR OCCC INMATES FOR MANSLAUGHTER IN DEATH OF CHRISTOPHER VAEFAGAPosted on Dec 28, 2023 in
Latest Department News, Newsroom
DEPARTMENT OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL
KA Ê»OIHANA O KA LOIO KUHINA
JOSH GREEN, M.D.
GOVERNOR
KE KIAÊ»Ä€INA
ANNE LOPEZ
ATTORNEY GENERAL
LOIO KUHINA
News Release 2023-64
GRAND JURY INDICTS FOUR OCCC INMATES FOR MANSLAUGHTER IN DEATH OF CHRISTOPHER VAEFAGA
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
December 28, 2023
HONOLULU â€“ An Oâ€˜ahu grand jury indicted four inmates at Oâ€˜ahu Community Correctional Center (OCCC)â€”Aaron Tuitelapaga, 29; Bronson Tuitelelepaga, 27; Manu Sorenson, 33; and Josiah Palimoomanu, 33â€”for Manslaughter in the death of Christopher Vaefaga, 36, another OCCC inmate.
The four defendants allegedly beat Vaefaga to death on July 6, 2023.
First Circuit Court Judge Ronald G. Johnson ordered that Tuitelapaga, Tuitelelepaga, and Sorensen be held without bail. Judge Johnson set Palimoomanuâ€™s bail at $500,000.
The Department of the Attorney Generalâ€™s Investigations Division conducted the investigation in this matter. The Departmentâ€™s Criminal Justice Division is prosecuting the case.
Manslaughter is a felony punishable by up to 20 years in prison.
The case is State of Hawaiâ€˜i v. Tuitelapaga, et al., Case No. 1CPC-23-0001488. Each of the four defendants is presumed innocent unless and until proven guilty.
###

title: HistÃ³ricas lluvias caen en el desierto de Sahara
text: HistÃ³ricas lluvias caen en el desierto de Sahara Se dice que la cantidad recibida de lluvias en varios dÃ­as es equivalente a lo que el Sahara ha recibido en aÃ±os. El [desierto del Sahara](https://www.elimparcial.com/tags/desierto-del-sahara/) es conocido por ser una de las zonas mÃ¡s calientes, desoladas y por supuesto aridas del [mundo](https://www.elimparcial.com/mundo/), ha sido escenario de un fenÃ³meno poco comÃºn: intensas lluvias abarcaron la gran y cÃ¡lida regiÃ³n. Este evento, ocurrido entre septiembre y principios de octubre de 2024, ha cambiado temporalmente el paisaje de las arenas del Sahara, creando cuerpos de agua donde antes solo habÃ­a sequedad. Te puede interesar: [AsÃ­ fue el Ãºltimo gran huracÃ¡n que azotÃ³ Tampa Bay](https://www.elimparcial.com/mexico/2024/10/10/asi-fue-el-ultimo-gran-huracan-que-azoto-tampa-bay/) Lluvias histÃ³ricas Las lluvias fueron provocadas por una tormenta extratropical que desplazÃ³ grandes cantidades de humedad hacia el sur de Marruecos, una zona que normalmente recibe menos de 25 milÃ­metros de lluvia anualmente. En lugares como Tagounite, las precipitaciones alcanzaron mÃ¡s de 100 milÃ­metros en solo 24 horas, superando con creces el promedio anual. ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡­ | Por primera vez en dÃ©cadas, el desierto del Sahara se inundÃ³: â€œAparecieron lagunas azules con agua en el famoso desierto entre palmeras y dunas de arena". â€” â˜¨ âšœ EspÃ­ritu Templario News âšœ âœ  (@NonNobis10)[pic.twitter.com/SV4WMjgSck][October 10, 2024] Se dice que la cantidad recibida de lluvias en varios dÃ­as es equivalente a lo que el Sahara ha recibido en aÃ±os. Este fenÃ³meno ha sido descrito por meteorÃ³logos como uno de los eventos mÃ¡s significativos de las Ãºltimas dÃ©cadas, debido a la intensidad y la rapidez con que las lluvias cayeron sobre el desierto, incluso pintando ciertas zonas del desierto de verde. El regreso del lago Iriqui Uno de los impactos mÃ¡s notables de estas lluvias ha sido el llenado del lago Iriqui, un lecho seco ubicado entre las regiones de Zagora y Tata que llevaba cinco dÃ©cadas sin recibir agua. Las imÃ¡genes provenientes del desierto han mostrado que el agua ha vuelto a regiones, generando una especie de oasis temporal, pasando de la sequedad extrema a mostrar un nuevo lago donde solo habÃ­a arena. Â¿Un ejemplo del cambio climÃ¡tico? Las lluvias inusuales en el Sahara ha encendido la conversaciÃ³n sobre la realidad del cambio climÃ¡tico en el mundo, destacando un efecto en cadena que podrÃ­a dejar un gran impacto. El fenÃ³meno de lluvias inusuales en el Sahara ha planteado preguntas sobre el impacto del cambio climÃ¡tico en la regiÃ³n. CientÃ­ficos y meteorÃ³logos han seÃ±alado que estas precipitaciones podrÃ­an ser un indicio de alteraciones en los patrones climÃ¡ticos tradicionales. Los cientÃ­ficos estÃ¡n analizando la posible conexiÃ³n entre estas lluvias y el cambio climÃ¡tico, asÃ­ como el desplazamiento de la Zona de Convergencia Intertropical (ZCIT), que podrÃ­a haber facilitado el transporte de humedad hacia el norte del Sahara. Este tipo de fenÃ³meno podrÃ­a ser un indicio de cambios a largo plazo en los patrones climÃ¡ticos de la regiÃ³n, que podrÃ­an volver mÃ¡s comunes las precipitaciones en zonas que histÃ³ricamente han sido extremadamente secas. author: @nbc6
title: Florida priest accused of biting woman during communion dispute
text: A priest could face charges after he allegedly bit a woman during a dispute over the Holy Communion at a [Florida](/tag/florida) church. The alleged incident happened Sunday at St. Thomas Aquinas Catholic Church in St. Cloud, less than 30 miles south of Orlando. According to a St. Cloud Police report, the incident happened during Mass. The woman told police that when she went to receive communion, the priest allegedly refused because he claimed she hadn't performed the prerequisite of Confession required by the Catholic Church to receive the Eucharist. When the woman responded that she had done so, the priest became upset and she said he tried to ram the communion wafer into her mouth, according to the report. Get South Florida local news, weather forecasts and entertainment stories to your inbox. [Sign up for NBC South Florida newsletters.] She said she then placed her hand in the vessel and tried to grab another wafer, "crushing them," the report said. The priest allegedly struggled with the woman, "who refused to let go," and that's when the priest "bit her hand so she would let go." In an interview with police captured on body camera video, the priest can be heard saying the woman attacked him first. "She pushed me and grabbed, and I have the bowl with the holy host, for us is sacred, and she grabbed all the hosts in her hands because she wants to receive for herself, which is not permitted," the priest explained. Local He admitted to biting the woman's arm after he said she wouldn't let go of the communion tray. The Diocese of Orlando said the priest responded in a way that was aimed "to protect the Holy Communion from this sacrilegious act." "While the Diocese of Orlando does not condone physical altercations such as this, in good faith, Father Rodriguez was simply attempting to prevent an act of desecration of the Holy Communion," it said. The Eucharist, the church said, "is not something a person can arbitrarily demand and is certainly not a mere 'cookie' as the complainant called it." The priest hasn't been arrested, but the woman said she plans on pressing charges. The police department turned information over to the state attorney's office for review.

Uno de los primeros momentos que mostrarÃ¡n los protagonistas son los preparativos de [una fiesta de fin de aÃ±o en la mansiÃ³n exclusiva que el conductor tiene en Punta del Este](https://lol.larepublica.pe/famosos/2024/01/02/marcelo-tinelli-feliz-pasar-ano-nuevo-milett-figueroa-sus-hijos-nada-mejor-que-eso-instagram-94356) (Uruguay). â€œMostrar la intimidad me parece que hoy forma parte de algo lindo, de algo que te acerca a la gente. Gracias por existirâ€, dijo Candelaria.

author: @BBCSport
title: Wilson reaches Players Championship semi-finals
text:
Wilson reaches Players Championship semi-finals
- Published
World champion Kyren Wilson progressed to the semi-finals of the Players Championship in Telford with a 6-3 win against Mark Williams.
The world number two raced into a 2-0 lead but a risky shot allowed Williams to get off the mark, before a break of 68 levelled the match.
The two continued to battle by taking a frame each but breaks of 61, 79 and 71 ensured Wilson took the next three frames to win.
"Mark's so good you can't allow him into a match and at 2-0 I should have gone into the interval at least 3-1 up," Wilson told ITV4.
"If anything, Mark probably felt he won that little mini-session to go 2-2 so it was about resetting, going into the practice room, hitting a few balls and I came out and won the next frame to go 3-2 and it set me back on the right path."
Wilson will next play either Mark Selby or Neil Robertson in the last four.
Meanwhile, China's Xiao Guodong beat compatriot Wu Yize 6-5 in the first round and will next face a quarter-final against John Higgins, who beat Chris Wakelin 6-5.

author: M A Hossain
title: BRICS challenges Western sanctions amid US â€˜theftâ€™ of sovereign assets
text:
In a recent policy shift, the US government, under President Joe Biden, has taken steps to leverage frozen Russian assets to support Ukraine amidst the ongoing conflict. The announcement, made by Biden on October 23, revealed the USâ€™s intention to use these frozen funds to repay a US$20 billion loan extended to Ukraine, which is part of a broader US$50 billion aid package by the G7 nations. This move has sparked outrage from Moscow, which views it as â€œtheftâ€ being elevated to the level of official government policy.
The Russian Embassy in the US quickly condemned the decision, describing it as a significant escalation in the use of seized sovereign assets, labeling it a neocolonial approach led by a â€œsmall group of countriesâ€. The embassy stressed that these actions are not only illegal but have been broadly rejected on the international stage. Russia has maintained that the confiscation of its assets, which began soon after the escalation of the Ukraine conflict in 2022, would be seen as theft, and it has warned of possible retaliatory actions.
According to Biden, the decision to use windfall profits from blocked Russian funds to aid Ukraine allows for financial assistance without burdening US taxpayers. Since the conflictâ€™s escalation, Washington has provided Ukraine with over US$64 billion in military aid, making it Kievâ€™s largest benefactor in the war. Bidenâ€™s latest move further entrenches US involvement, with the new financial package aiming to assist Ukraineâ€™s war efforts and recovery without causing additional strain on domestic budgets.
This development comes on the heels of similar announcements from the European Union and the United Kingdom, both of which have also promised loans to Ukraine, with repayments drawn from frozen Russian assets. These steps signify a growing trend among Western nations to utilize confiscated Russian funds to support Ukraineâ€™s war effort and its recovery, a move that Russia strongly opposes.
The broader international response to this strategy has been critical. The Russian Embassy highlighted the outcome of the BRICS summit in Kazan, where the leaders of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa (BRICS) condemned these actions. The summit resulted in a joint declaration that called for multilateral efforts to construct a new, independent financial architecture, one that would protect countries from the â€œillegal actionsâ€ being promoted by Western powers. This aligns with BRICSâ€™ broader opposition to unilateral sanctions, which the group sees as undermining global trade and economic stability.
The Kazan Declaration, adopted by the BRICS nations, is a clear expression of their vision for a fairer international order. The group reaffirmed its commitment to a multipolar world, where no single country or bloc holds overwhelming sway over global affairs. In this context, they condemned Western sanctions, particularly the freezing of Russian sovereign assets, as unlawful and inconsistent with the principles of international law.
The declaration also emphasized the need for all nations to have equal representation in global governance structures. This is a long-standing grievance of BRICS members, who argue that institutions like the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank remain too heavily influenced by Western interests. BRICS countries have called for reforms to these organizations to give emerging economies a greater voice. The group also promoted the use of local currencies in trade between BRICS nations and their partners, aiming to reduce reliance on the US dollar and euro in global commerce.
The freezing of Russian assets in the wake of the Ukraine conflict, estimated at around US$300 billion, has had significant implications for the global financial system. Despite pressure from some quarters to permanently confiscate these assets, the IMF has resisted the move, fearing that such a step could erode trust in the Western-dominated financial architecture. Moscow has consistently labeled these actions as theft and has vowed to respond in kind if its assets are seized permanently.
The Kazan Declaration also addressed other pressing global issues, including the Ukraine conflict. However, the BRICS nations have maintained a neutral stance on the war, refusing to fully back either side. Instead, the group has called for a peaceful resolution through dialogue and diplomacy, in line with the principles of the United Nations Charter. This contrasts with the approach taken by Western nations, particularly the US, which continues to provide extensive military and financial support to Ukraine.
BRICS leaders have stressed that unilateral sanctions, like those imposed on Russia, have a disproportionately negative impact on developing countries and global economic stability. They pointed out that such measures often hinder progress towards achieving sustainable development goals, as they exacerbate poverty and inequality in the targeted nations. The Kazan Declaration also criticized the use of economic measures disguised as environmental or climate concerns, which it claims are used to justify protectionist policies that disrupt global supply chains and create unfair competition.
The declarationâ€™s strong language reflects growing frustration within BRICS about Western hegemony in global trade and finance. The groupâ€™s leaders are pushing for greater cooperation among emerging markets and developing countries (EMDCs), and they have opened the door for new members to join BRICS in the future. This would expand the blocâ€™s influence and potentially reshape the global economic order.
While the Ukraine conflict has drawn significant attention from the international community, the Kazan Declaration made it clear that the BRICS nations view the war as just one of many issues facing the world. For them, the focus remains on building a more inclusive and balanced global system, one that allows for sovereign equality and rejects the coercive measures currently favored by the West.
In conclusion, the USâ€™s decision to use frozen Russian assets to support Ukraine marks a significant escalation in the use of sovereign funds as a tool of war. This has drawn sharp criticism from Russia and its allies, who view the move as illegal and destabilizing. The Kazan Declaration, adopted at the recent BRICS summit, provides a counter-narrative to Western policies, promoting a vision of global governance that rejects unilateral actions and prioritizes multilateral cooperation. The declaration also highlights the need for a new financial architecture that protects countries from the kinds of coercive measures currently being employed by the US and its allies.
Please follow Blitz on Google News Channel

title: FranÃ§ois Cluzet bouleversant sur son enfance difficile : "On a vÃ©cu des trucs trÃ¨s dangereux"
text:

FranÃ§ois Cluzet, actuellement au thÃ©Ã¢tre avec la piÃ¨ce Encore une journÃ©e Divine, sâ€™est confiÃ© Ã  cÅ“ur ouvert Ã  propos de son enfance difficile dans les colonnes de Paris Match.
Passer la publicitÃ©
Ã€ propos de
Des confidences bouleversantes... FranÃ§ois Cluzet fait son grand retour sur les planches aprÃ¨s 25 ans dâ€™absence avec la piÃ¨ce Encore une journÃ©e Divine, au ThÃ©Ã¢tre des Bouffes Parisiens, Ã  partir de ce jeudi 30 janvier, dans laquelle il incarne un psychologue internÃ© en hÃ´pital psychiatrique. Le comÃ©dien sâ€™est confiÃ© Ã  lâ€™occasion de ce nouveau projet sur scÃ¨ne dans les colonnes du magazine Paris Match sur les traumatismes de son enfance qui lâ€™ont menÃ© Ã  suivre une thÃ©rapie pendant huit ans. Â« Je vivais un traumatisme dâ€™enfance. Je nâ€™arrivais pas Ã  dÃ©mÃªler qui avait fait quoi entre mon pÃ¨re et ma mÃ¨re. Ma mÃ¨re est partie quand jâ€™avais huit ans. Mon pÃ¨re est devenu dÃ©pressif et on a vÃ©cu mon frÃ¨re et moi des trucs trÃ¨s dangereux Â», partage-t-il, et dâ€™ajouter : Â« MÃªme si, sur le moment, jâ€™ai aimÃ© mon enfance, comme tous les gosses, je me suis marrÃ© en classe, je dÃ©connais, tout allait bien. Mais lorsque le succÃ¨s est arrivÃ© tout Ã§a mâ€™est tombÃ© sur la gueule. Â»
Lâ€™acteur a commencÃ© Ã  faire face Ã  ses traumatismes Ã  lâ€™Ã¢ge de 19, lorsquâ€™il Ã©tait au Cours Simon. Il voulait travailler sur sa sensibilitÃ© et câ€™est alors mis Ã  boire et Ã  consommer des drogues. Â« Cela a fini par me jouer des tours.
